Use a real-world case to expose the pain points of iOS BLE and the divergent reasoning paths of Codex and Claude Code as AI assistants.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

When you build cross-platform BLE, iOS is always the pickier one. We were integrating with a blood glucose pump, and Android sailed through while iOS refused to respond. Even more interesting, two AI assistants—Codex and Claude Code—returned completely different answers. In the end, Codex hit the mark; Claude Code did not. This article reconstructs the entire process and talks about how “AI debugging styles” can differ.

Preface

Section titled “Preface”

When building cross-platform Bluetooth applications, the BLE (Bluetooth Low Energy) stack on iOS often gives developers headaches. Recently our team faced a tricky iOS BLE connection problem, especially when connecting to a blood glucose pump. The interesting twist: two different AI assistants—Codex and Claude Code—produced entirely different solutions, and only Codex succeeded.

This article digs into the essence of the problem, contrasts the two lines of reasoning, and offers guidance for developers who run into similar issues.

  • Platform: iOS (CoreBluetooth framework + BabyBluetooth library)
  • Framework: Flutter cross-platform app, communicating with native iOS through Platform Channels
  • Device: Blood glucose pump (Bluetooth medical device)

Section titled “Claude Code’s Diagnostic Steps”

Claude Code diagnosed the problem as a connection timeout, focusing on:

  1. Initial assessment: Assumed iOS connects more slowly than Android
  2. Attempted fix: Added a 20-second timeout (to match Android’s setting)

  1. Second attempt: Noticed a 2-second delay before the “connection success” callback
  1. Final result: Removing the delay still failed to resolve the issue

Codex’s Diagnostic Steps

Section titled “Codex’s Diagnostic Steps”

Codex correctly identified the true nature of the problem—a race condition:

  1. Root-cause analysis:

    • Service discovery on iOS is asynchronous
    • Flutter immediately calls setNotifyByUuid and writeByUuid after a successful connection
    • At that moment the services and characteristics may not have been discovered yet
    • That causes the operations to fail

2. Cache Failed Requests inside setNotifyByUuid

  • Inspect timing issues

3. Simulate Asynchronous Delay

Section titled “3. Simulate Asynchronous Delay”

Summary

Section titled “Summary”

This case highlights how critical it is to understand the underlying framework when doing cross-platform BLE development. Codex succeeded by:

  1. Pinpointing the true root cause: a race condition, not a timeout
  2. Mastering iOS BLE’s async behavior: recognizing the asynchronous discovery flow
  3. Designing an elegant fix: pending-operation queue plus retry logic
  4. Staying backward compatible: no disruptive changes to the Flutter layer

By contrast, Claude Code’s failure reminds us:

  • Surface symptoms can be misleading
  • You must analyze the asynchronous call chain
  • Fixing symptoms alone won’t eliminate the root cause

Hopefully this write-up helps developers dealing with similar iOS BLE issues. Remember: with asynchronous code, timing issues usually matter more than timeouts.

References

Section titled “References”
  1. Apple Core Bluetooth Programming Guide
  2. BabyBluetooth iOS BLE Library
  3. Flutter Platform Channels
  4. iOS BLE Best Practices

Our Conclusion

Section titled “Our Conclusion”

Whether it’s Claude Code or Codex, the process is still “hypothesize + verify.” Codex won this time because it guessed the race-condition root cause correctly from the start. Give Claude Code a few more runs and it could converge on the right answer too—iteration plus evidence eventually lands the fix. That’s the reality of “AI-led debugging”: assumptions, trial and error, and proof.

Key Takeaways Cheat Sheet (with Authoritative References)

Section titled “Key Takeaways Cheat Sheet (with Authoritative References)”
  • CoreBluetooth discovery and callbacks are asynchronous. Operate only after the corresponding callbacks (such as discoverServices or discoverCharacteristics:forService:) complete; precise UUID searches are more efficient.
  • “Discover first, then act” is the conventional order for iOS BLE. Tutorials and field guides emphasize callback-driven, asynchronous thinking to avoid writing before discovery finishes.
  • You can discover services/characteristics via full-table or targeted UUIDs. Full scans are slower; targeted discovery is more stable.
  • BabyBluetooth wraps CoreBluetooth with block- and chain-style APIs, making it easier to flush deferred queues inside setBlockOnDiscoverCharacteristics.
  • Flutter Platform Channels bridge Dart and iOS/Android; the business-layer timing guarantees should live on the native side so Dart can’t dispatch writes prematurely.

Practical Checklist

Section titled “Practical Checklist”

Do these six things and iOS BLE stops tormenting you:

  • Align the sequence: lock “connect → service → characteristic → notify → write” into a state machine and reject writes until Ready.
  • Build a queue: enqueue write operations and notify requests, flush them in the callbacks.
  • Add idempotency: repeated setNotify/write calls must be re-entrant to prevent “write storms.”
  • Add retries: exponential backoff + retry limits, backed by detailed logs.
  • Cache aggressively: cache services/characteristics and maintain connection pools to lower overhead.
  • Layer responsibilities: let Flutter “look successful,” but iOS must own correctness.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

The age of artificial intelligence (AI) has arrived with a bang. From business owners to team leaders to frontline engineers, everyone’s role at work is quietly shifting. Some worry that AI will take their jobs; others are excited by the surge in efficiency. The reality is that AI is reshaping how we work at astonishing speed. How should decisions be made? How do we use the tools? How should we lead? And for introverted engineers who prefer heads‑down work in particular, is this the moment to shine—or will the social naturals race ahead? This piece looks at real cases and data to see how Bosses, Leaders, and engineers can each find new advantages in the AI tide.

Decision‑Making and Role Redesign: What Is AI Taking Over?

Section titled “Decision‑Making and Role Redesign: What Is AI Taking Over?”

AI is redrawing the workplace map. Decisions once made by people are now informed by algorithms—and in some cases automated end‑to‑end. Resume screening in HR, reconciliation in finance, and other routine workflows are increasingly handled by AI, freeing managers from administrative grind. Business owners (Bosses) can therefore focus more on strategic direction while delegating day‑to‑day operational decisions to data.

IgniteTech’s CEO Eric Vaughan took a radical step: pushing the company “All in AI,” replacing as much as 80% of staff and keeping only those willing to embrace AI. He argues that “people who don’t use AI will be replaced by those who do.” The results? Within three months of the transition, process‑optimization metrics improved by 300% across departments, and the finance team cut the quarterly close from five days to 48 hours. For many responsibilities, AI didn’t just add speed—it changed the game.

Leaders (team managers) are approving and monitoring less, but they now own the job of putting AI strategy into practice: training teams on new tools and re‑architecting processes. As Andrew Ng notes, AI gives small teams the power to rival big companies: a single engineer finishing in a day what used to take six months of prototyping is no longer a myth. That reality is loosening traditional hierarchies and pushing decision rights down to the technologists on the front lines.

On the engineering side, parts of basic coding and testing are auto‑generated, pulling engineers up into higher‑level design and optimization. Newcomers, with AI support, can deliver products in a language they don’t yet know within days. AI is redefining role boundaries: it frees people from repetition, but it also requires continuous upskilling and new responsibilities in human‑AI collaboration.

Tooling and Efficiency Leaps: How Is AI Changing the Pace of Work?

Section titled “Tooling and Efficiency Leaps: How Is AI Changing the Pace of Work?”

In the AI wave, new tools are proliferating and accelerating the pace of work. For developers, GitHub Copilot and similar code assistants feel like pair‑programming with a tireless partner; official data shows it has increased development speed by 55%. And it’s not just programmers—nearly every role now has an AI helper: marketers brainstorm with ChatGPT, designers use Midjourney to generate concept art, and product managers lean on smart analytics to interpret user data.

According to a joint Microsoft and LinkedIn study, 75% of employees already use generative AI at work, and 68% say their workload and tempo are more demanding than before—yet AI is helping them cope. Many even bring their own AI tools to work (especially in SMBs). This “AI‑partner” model dramatically boosts personal throughput—tasks that used to require a team can now be done by one person plus AI.

Leaders can therefore reallocate people from mechanical, repetitive work to creative, higher‑value problems. Microsoft’s Copilot for Office, for instance, can automatically capture meeting takeaways and generate action items, smoothing team collaboration.

Business owners are actively arming their teams, too: companies like IgniteTech reimburse every employee for ChatGPT Plus and set up dedicated “AI Days” for intensive practice. Forward‑looking Bosses have found that employees who embrace AI typically produce more—and they reward that with bonuses and promotions. Surveys show that more than two‑thirds of leaders say they won’t hire candidates who know nothing about AI; even less experienced candidates who are fluent with AI are preferred.

Engineers are also experiencing “AI hyper‑growth”: some use AI to rapidly fill skill gaps; juniors, with Copilot, produce mid‑level code; seniors become the fabled “10x engineers.” The flip side of tooling is fiercer competition—those who don’t learn AI are getting left behind. For those willing to learn, however, AI is becoming a force‑multiplier for productivity.

Leadership Style Shift: From Controller to Enabler

Section titled “Leadership Style Shift: From Controller to Enabler”

With AI and greater information transparency, leaders must evolve their role. The classic manager once acted like a commander—controlling the field and making every call. Today, AI makes analysis and options far more accessible, and frontline employees can propose data‑driven recommendations. In this environment, Leaders who cling to “I decide everything” risk slowing innovation.

As Andrew Ng has said, when “10x talent” emerges on a team, “the best person to make a decision is sometimes the engineer, not the manager.” Traditional pyramids push information up and ask leaders to decide. In the AI era, specialists armed with intelligent tools hold rich context and alternatives—and should receive greater decision autonomy.

Successful leaders are starting to play the roles of “gardener” and coach: creating fertile ground for trial‑and‑error and innovation rather than doing everything themselves. Modern organizations must distribute decision rights throughout the structure so experts at the edge can respond quickly. That requires Leaders to trust their teams, let go more, and bring technically savvy frontline colleagues into important decisions.

The same applies to the Boss level: many business owners now establish a Chief AI Officer (CAIO) role, weaving AI strategy into executive decision‑making and asking functions to report regularly to the AI team.

Beyond delegation, leadership is getting “softer.” Because AI can offer objective options, leaders increasingly need empathy and judgment to balance technology with humanity. One clear trend: managers are investing more in team learning. Surveys show that as many as 62% of employees feel they lack the skills to use AI effectively and safely, while only about one in ten believe they have what they need. In response, leaders are providing AI training resources to close the skills gap—for example, some companies host a monthly “AI Sharing Day,” with leaders participating alongside employees.

In short, AI‑era leadership is shifting from command‑and‑control to empowerment‑and‑collaboration. Not everyone who uses AI is a “junior”; the leaders who can activate these “AI power users” will be the ones who pull their teams ahead.

Opportunities for Introverted Engineers: How Does AI Amplify Quiet Strength?

Section titled “Opportunities for Introverted Engineers: How Does AI Amplify Quiet Strength?”

AI affects engineers differently, but for many who are introverted and technically strong, this may be the best moment to shine. In the past, outspoken teammates could attract attention by presenting well, while introverts—even highly capable ones—might remain unnoticed. Today, AI tools can act as an amplifier for expression and a superb partner for execution.

There’s a growing view that AI offers introverts new ways to collaborate and express ideas—letting thinking cut through social friction and reach the heart of the problem. Introverted engineers no longer need to worry as much about “performing” in front of others; they can focus on deep thought and high‑quality output. Their ability for independent inquiry is being amplified as never before.

Real‑world stories back this up. In one software team, several quiet members flourished after adopting AI. They used models to better understand customer feedback, then engaged clients with greater confidence—ultimately improving results significantly. Picture an engineer skilled at independent problem‑solving, paired with an AI copilot; together they may produce what used to take a ten‑person team. These quiet “deep divers,” once aided by AI, can deliver startling results.

Notably, the AI era is making “10x engineers” more common—they may say little, but by mastering the tools, they work several times faster than most. Companies are willing to pay for such talent; top engineers may earn three times an average engineer’s compensation.

That said, introverted engineers must beware the comfort‑zone trap. Over‑reliance on AI as a substitute for communication can weaken social skills. On one hand, AI makes it easier for introverts to stand out on the strength of their work. On the other, excellent engineers don’t avoid communication—they use AI to boost their technical articulation and still invest in the human collaboration that AI can’t replace. Play to your strengths while shoring up gaps, and the “quiet” technologist can become a surprising disruptor in the AI age.

Role Changes at a Glance

Section titled “Role Changes at a Glance”

Below is a table summarizing how Bosses, Leaders, and engineers are changing in the AI era, and how to respond:

Dimension of ChangeBoss (Business Owner)Leader (Team Manager)Engineer (incl. introverts)
Decision‑making & workflowMore data‑driven decisions; heavy automation of daily processes; flatter structures with more frontline authority.Fewer transactional approvals; focus on strategic guidance; emphasize cross‑functional collaboration; reshape processes for AI.AI handles repetitive tasks; engineers focus on high‑value work; more chances to deliver end‑to‑end independently.
AI tool adoptionDrive AI enablement company‑wide; invest in AI infra and training; learn AI personally to set direction.Lead by example; spread AI tools to raise team efficiency; use AI to watch metrics and assist management.Everyone has an AI assistant (coding, writing, etc.); productivity surges; keep learning new tools and become an “AI power user.”
Management/collaboration styleShift from command to empowerment; encourage bottom‑up innovation; foster an open learning culture.Delegate to experts; act as mentor and coordinator; emphasize empathy and communication to rally the team.More autonomy and remote collaboration; use AI to aid expression (smart docs, chatbots) and improve team efficiency.
Skills and traits neededUnderstand AI strategy and ethics; decide fast to capture AI opportunities; embrace change and continual learning.Working AI literacy to guide the team; data‑driven judgment; higher EQ; change‑management capability.Deep domain skills + AI fluency; introverts add communication skills; combine independence with teamwork.
Advantages and opportunitiesUse AI to cut cost and raise output; small teams achieve big results; agile transformation wins market timing.Free management bandwidth to focus on strategy and innovation; build a resilient, “AI‑native” team.Talent value polarizes; those who master AI rise faster in pay and role; introverts stand out as scarce 10x talent.

Conclusion: Ride the Wave and Find Your Edge

Section titled “Conclusion: Ride the Wave and Find Your Edge”

In the AI era, no one is untouched—but no one is fated to be left behind. The key is to move with the current. Bosses need foresight: embrace AI so the company runs faster, while keeping a human touch so technology doesn’t devolve into cold KPIs. Leaders must shift posture—from order‑giver to team coach—helping everyone grow, arming the team with AI while rallying people with sincerity. Engineers should stay curious and keep learning, treating AI as a trusted copilot while pushing the ceiling of their own skills.

Introvert or extrovert, everyone can find a point of leverage in the AI wave—perhaps a distinctive specialty you can own end‑to‑end, or a cross‑disciplinary idea that breaks new ground. Used well, AI is a double‑edged sword: offload the mechanical to machines and bring your creativity and warmth to the forefront.

In this age of change, roles can be redefined, but effort and insight remain the surest path to advantage. May we each find our edge in the AI era, ride the wind, and evolve together.

item.title: Writing Code Is Surface—Thinking Is the Essence of Software Development
item.content:encoded:
“Code is just a tool; thinking is the core.”

If you’re a product manager, indie maker, or junior developer, that line may feel counterintuitive. Yet in day‑to‑day engineering, we repeatedly discover: programming is 90% thinking and 10% typing. With Claude Code, ChatGPT, and Google Gemini making code generation easier than ever, this truth is now crystal clear. If AI can write code for us—where does our value really lie?

Consider a few common scenes: to deliver a seemingly simple feature, a developer spends ages on design—then needs only half a day to write the code. Or a production bug takes two days to investigate from logs to root cause—but the fix is a single line. PMs often wonder: “It’s just a small feature—why so long to write some code?” The reality: coding has never been the hardest part. The hard part is “what exactly are we building, and how?” Software development is fundamentally about thinking, not mechanical typing.

In an AI‑accelerated era, this stands out even more. Over 81% of developers now use AI coding assistants. One bank’s tech team reported a 40% reduction in coding time and a defect‑detection accuracy up to 92% after adopting an assistant—yet the lead still emphasized: “AI‑generated code requires human review—especially around security logic and business rules. Developers must remain in charge.” In the end, concurrency control written by AI was revised by humans due to potential risks. The essence of human‑AI collaboration is clear: AI handles repetitive, standardized work; humans handle creative, complex decisions. In other words, AI can be your “helper” that outputs code—but what ultimately determines software success is still the thinking and judgment in your head.

Below, we’ll walk through real everyday scenarios to see how “thinking” dominates—and how AI coding assistants take over the busywork so you can focus on what matters most.

Scenario 1: Implementing business features — think first, then code

Section titled “Scenario 1: Implementing business features — think first, then code”

When a new requirement lands, newcomers often rush to code. Experienced engineers suppress that impulse and first invest heavily in understanding the business: what problem does the requirement solve? What rules and edge cases exist? How should data flow? Only after clarifying the logic can we write correct code. Coding is translating a mental design into a language a computer executes. The translation isn’t the hard part—having the design is.

Take a familiar task: implement “order placement deducts inventory” in e‑commerce. The time sink is clarifying the rules behind “deduct inventory”—what happens if stock is insufficient? How do we prevent overselling under concurrency? How do we roll back on failure? Each question demands careful thought and design. By comparison, the final call to the inventory service to decrement a number may be only a few lines. If the logic isn’t thought through, more code won’t save you; if it is, the code is often just a handful of lines.

With AI tools, “think before you code” becomes more efficient. Once you’ve designed the logic, ask ChatGPT or Claude to produce a first pass of the implementation—saving time and effort. But note: AI won’t think through requirements for you. It doesn’t grasp the business essence; it only generates code from your description. You must be the “brain,” conveying intent precisely. In a way, AI forces us to be more rigorous: instructions must be clear, or the output will drift. Once again: before writing business code, think through the business logic. Code quality rises and falls with the depth of your thinking.

Scenario 2: Integrating third‑party APIs — understanding beats typing

Section titled “Scenario 2: Integrating third‑party APIs — understanding beats typing”

Many of us have integrated a third‑party API. At first glance, it seems like “just a few HTTP calls”—but where’s the real time sink? Reading and understanding the documentation: which URL does what, what parameters are required, how to auth/sign, response formats, what error cases to handle. Mapping the flow and edge cases can consume hours before a single line of code is written.

For example, integrating a payment platform: you have to find the correct endpoint, understand the order schema, learn the retry strategy and error codes, then design your system’s call sequence and resilience. Once that’s clear, the coding is mostly assembling HTTP requests and parsing responses. With AI helpers, this gets easier; you can paste relevant docs or schemas and have AI draft the client code.

But API integration fundamentally tests learning and comprehension. We play the role of “translator,” turning a foreign system into local code. AI accelerates translation, but it can’t replace grasping the “original meaning.” Without context, AI might miss key parameters or misuse flows—leaving traps for humans to catch later. So invest time in understanding the API’s business meaning and planning the call strategy, not just in the mechanics of writing the code. With that mindset—and AI to produce the scaffolding—you’ll get twice the results for half the effort.

Scenario 3: Fixing bugs — analysis costs more than the edit

Section titled “Scenario 3: Fixing bugs — analysis costs more than the edit”

Debugging is everyday life. As the joke goes: “30 minutes to write, 3 hours to debug.” When a bug appears, the first step isn’t editing code—it’s investigation: reproduce, inspect logs, read surrounding code, hypothesize likely causes, and narrow the search. It’s a mystery to solve—logic, inference, and understanding the system deeply. Once you find the root, the change is often trivial.

Imagine maintaining a complex system when sporadic errors are reported. You pore over logs to triangulate the module; add debug prints and replay runs to isolate conditions; even sketch a flowchart to unravel the execution path. After this mental work, you discover a missing null check in a rare branch. Adding that guard takes five minutes—the time went into thinking and locating, not typing.

Where can AI help? Today, AI is a capable assistant, not a substitute. You can feed failing code and logs to ChatGPT to brainstorm likely causes—it often produces useful leads. But deciding the truth and validating hypotheses still falls to you. Real debugging involves the project’s context, architecture, and business logic; it’s rarely “one faulty line.” Without the full picture, AI suggestions can be off‑target. Humans carry the global model of the system, weigh signals, and decide.

Some tools are improving here. Anthropic’s Claude is strong at step‑by‑step reasoning, listing thorough investigation steps; OpenAI’s ChatGPT is quick with obvious fixes. Treat them like a conversational mirror and advisor—explaining symptoms to clarify your own thinking and catch missed details. Even if AI proposes a patch, validate it carefully. Debugging remains a human‑led exploration and inference process; AI accelerates insight.

Scenario 4: Writing tests — designing cases matters more than code

Section titled “Scenario 4: Writing tests — designing cases matters more than code”

“No tests, no quality.” Writing tests is another case where design outweighs typing: the hardest part is imagining scenarios and cases—what to test, what can go wrong. Converting that into test code is relatively mechanical.

As one senior SDET put it: designing tests is sparring with your own code. You must dream up edge cases, boundary conditions, and invalid inputs to challenge robustness. For an order system, you might design: “What happens when demand exceeds stock?”, “How should order flow behave under DB connection drops?”, “Is the result consistent under 1,000 concurrent orders?” Each scenario demands deep understanding plus a critical mindset. That mental investment is most of the work; writing the asserts and fixtures is just staging the play.

The good news: AI shines at generating test code. You can feed a function and ask for targeted unit tests. It will often produce solid coverage and even infer developer intent from comments and context. But human judgment still decides whether tests are necessary, sufficient, and reasonable. As one developer quipped: “AI is great at turning ‘write a test to verify…’ into runnable code. Your job is to invent inputs that could break the code—without slogging through the boilerplate.”

Scenario 5: Designing technical solutions — architects live in the thinking layer

Section titled “Scenario 5: Designing technical solutions — architects live in the thinking layer”

When planning a new system or technical approach, engineers switch to pure thinking mode: a new recommendation algorithm, a microservices layout, or a sharding plan. Little to no production code is written at first. We apply experience, knowledge, and creativity to sketch the blueprint on a whiteboard or in a doc.

We consider: business and non‑functional requirements (performance, scalability, security, etc.); possible options and their trade‑offs and complexity; and which path is most robust. This is mental work. We draw architecture diagrams, enumerate modules, and write design docs—visualized thinking that clarifies the path. Once the plan is set, implementation comes later.

AI can assist here too: have ChatGPT show pattern examples, industry best practices, or produce an outline for you to refine. But the architect—grounded in business context—makes the final call. If anything, AI’s rise highlights how architecture depends on human insight. General advice from corpora can’t know your team’s constraints or long‑term goals; only you can weigh them.

We’re also seeing early signs of “repository‑level” assistants that generate whole codebases from high‑level prompts. Tempting as “one‑click projects” sound, they’re not production‑ready today; outputs are often brittle. Even as they improve, they’ll still need architects to think through the design and feed it in. Research suggests these tools are most useful for freeing developers to focus on higher‑level design and deployment decisions—AI does the low‑level details, humans steer.

In short, when designing solutions, we are thinkers and decision‑makers—not just code craftsmen. A good design beats a poor implementation; a clear, reasonable design slashes build and maintenance costs. If you skip the thinking and rush into code, the hidden traps cost 10–100x later. AI doesn’t change this; it reinforces it: code can be delegated, but creative responsibility cannot.

Conclusion: Be a better thinker in the AI era

Section titled “Conclusion: Be a better thinker in the AI era”

Whether you’re a PM, indie maker, or new developer, hopefully these scenarios resonate: the core advantage in software isn’t typing code—it’s thinking deeply and solving problems. As the saying goes, “Programming is 90% thinking and 10% typing.” AI makes this truer than ever. With code generation offloaded, our value lies in asking the right questions, making sound decisions, and solving complex problems creatively—skills AI cannot yet replace.

For product managers, recognizing the “thinking load” in development helps set better timelines and expectations. When a dev estimates a week, don’t fixate on lines of code; appreciate the design tradeoffs and mental work. Try having AI produce a quick prototype; you’ll feel firsthand that moving from 0→1 is really about turning fuzzy goals into a clear plan. When the early thinking is done well, implementation flows.

For indie or full‑stack engineers, you wear many hats and must balance thinking vs. coding. With AI, offload repetitive work—scaffolds, CRUD, format conversions—and conserve your brainpower for choices only you can make: product ideas, architecture selection, and core algorithm design. Many of us are already shifting from “writing code” to “designing, decomposing, prompting, and reviewing.” The sooner you adapt, the more competitive you’ll be.

For juniors, don’t fear AI—or resign yourself to being its typist. Treat AI as mentor and tool. Ask “why,” and use it to learn higher‑level knowledge. Surveys show many developers’ top AI use case is learning—new tech, best practices, and more. First, analyze and design on your own; then ask AI for alternative implementations and compare. Learn fast by closing the gap. Avoid tossing problems to AI without understanding—otherwise you risk hollowing out your skills. AI ultimately serves thinkers. Those who don’t think will fall behind—this only becomes more true in the AI era.

Finally, AI coding assistants don’t let our brains go off duty. Quite the opposite: they push us to understand where our value lies. If typing is automatable, we should invest time in understanding the business deeply, designing carefully, enforcing quality, and innovating continuously. That won’t make us obsolete—it will make us more effective and creative.

Let AI be the “code laborer.” Let us be better “system designers” and “problem‑solving experts.” As we learn to delegate implementation to AI, we’ll find ideas ship faster, and once‑daunting tasks become manageable because we have more time to think. The essence of software remains thinking—unchanged, only now with clearer division of labor: machines write obediently; humans think wisely.

May this piece encourage you to bet on thinking—and to embrace AI as leverage. Offload the repetitive; let your mind create more value. 🎉

item.title: Bank Turmoil, Liquidity, and Tariffs: A Small‑Town Depositor’s Market Adventure
item.content:encoded:
This is a story about where money comes from and where it goes. The protagonist isn’t Wall Street—it’s us: salaries coming in, buying funds, skimming headlines… When two US regional banks run into trouble, the Fed hints at a “stop to balance‑sheet runoff,” the 10‑year Treasury yield dips below 4%, and rumors swirl about a potential US–China meeting—how do these seemingly far‑off events end up walking straight into our accounts?

Chapter 1 | The Teller’s “Bad News”

Section titled “Chapter 1 | The Teller’s “Bad News””

Early Friday, before the small‑town branch fills up, an alert flashes on the lobby display:

“Zions Bank disclosed a $50 million loan loss; Western Alliance said it filed a lawsuit in August against a borrower called Cantor Group V, suspecting collateral fraud.”

The branch manager whispers: “Not a systemic blow‑up—likely idiosyncratic fraud—but the stocks will sell off first and ask questions later.” The fixed‑income manager chimes in: “Don’t underestimate this; ‘surprises’ like these make people more afraid of risk—so they rush for safer debt.” Sure enough, the 10‑year Treasury yield intraday dipped toward ~3.93%–4%—prices up, yields down.

Aside: This isn’t “all banks are in trouble.” It’s that isolated cases tighten market nerves. When nerves tighten, money hides in bonds—and stocks are more prone to a quick “jump scare.”

Chapter 2 | The Edge of the Pool

Section titled “Chapter 2 | The Edge of the Pool”

Think of the financial system as a giant pool:

  • Fed balance‑sheet runoff (QT) = water draining slowly.
  • Treasury General Account (TGA) = the government’s storage tank; when it’s very full, the banking system temporarily gets less water.
  • Overnight Reverse Repo (ON RRP) = a “backup bucket” in the corner; once it’s empty, you rely more on the main pool.

On Tuesday, Chair Powell said:

“We may be approaching, over the next few months, a point to stop the runoff. We’re seeing signs—like repo rates—that liquidity is getting tighter.”

Meanwhile, the market is glued to the waterline of bank reserves—the main pool. As it drifts near ~$3 trillion, people ask: Can we keep draining without hitting the bottom? (See the weekly H.4.1.) The ON RRP “backup bucket” has almost been drained this year, meaning further “pulls” more directly touch bank reserves. On the fiscal side, the TGA sits around ~$850 billion in mid‑October—still quite full.

Aside: Low waterline + backup bucket near empty + a full storage tank makes people hug the “safe edge” (buy Treasuries). Equities get more selective.

Chapter 3 | Good Companies Still Get Rained On

Section titled “Chapter 3 | Good Companies Still Get Rained On”

Ironically, fundamentals aren’t bad.

  • ASML: Q3 net sales €7.5B, gross margin 51.6%; guided for a strong Q4 and even said 2026 won’t be below 2025.
  • TSMC: Q3 revenue $33.1B, gross margin 59.5%; Q4 outlook $32.2–$33.4B.

Aside: The rain isn’t falling from fundamentals; it’s coming from liquidity and sentiment. Companies with big umbrellas (strong cash flow, healthy balance sheets) dry off quickly.

Chapter 4 | Winds from Overseas: Rare Earths and Tariffs

Section titled “Chapter 4 | Winds from Overseas: Rare Earths and Tariffs”

More gusts arrive from the sea:

  • China expanded rare‑earth export controls on Oct 9 (added elements/tech), tightening global supply nerves.
  • In the US, talk of 100% tariffs ebbs and flows—headlines alternately harden and soften—while “will they meet around APEC” becomes a running cliffhanger.

Aside: These are exogenous shocks. Even if a company doesn’t change, its valuation may.

Chapter 5 | A “Rainy‑Day Trio” for New Investors

Section titled “Chapter 5 | A “Rainy‑Day Trio” for New Investors”

  1. First, watch the waterline (don’t be stubborn):

    • Clearer signals of stopping QT + repo rates easing = lighter rain.
    • With ON RRP near empty, if reserve balances stop falling and stabilize, that’s an early “clearing” sign.
    • If the 10‑year yield holds around ~4% (or breaks lower and doesn’t snap back), risk appetite can recover.

  2. Next, pick your umbrella (don’t over‑optimize):

    • Leaders with steady cash flow and healthy balance sheets (e.g., upstream semi equipment/foundry) better withstand showers.
    • When bank idiosyncrasies pop up, keep sector exposure lighter and more diversified until disclosures are clearer.

  3. Finally, mind the sea breeze (don’t tune it out):

    • The path of rare earths and tariffs drives manufacturing costs and valuations; around key meetings, read twice before acting.

Chapter 6 | One‑Page Memo

Section titled “Chapter 6 | One‑Page Memo”
  • Spark for this bout: idiosyncratic regional‑bank credit issues → risk‑off → bonds up/yields down → equities pressured.
  • Deeper water forces: hints that QT is nearing its end + reserve “lower bound” + RRP near empty + elevated TGA.
  • Fundamental contrast: leaders still strong (ASML, TSMC).
  • Biggest external swing factor: rare‑earth and tariff headlines tug at valuations.

One‑sentence strategy: Treat this as a “liquidity shower,” not a “house collapse.” Go lighter and stagger entries while it pours; run faster when it clears. Three weather gauges: (1) stop‑QT signals (2) reserves and RRP (3) the 10‑year yield.

Bonus | “Why do headlines obsess over yields?”

Section titled “Bonus | “Why do headlines obsess over yields?””

Because yields are like the market’s thermometer:

  • When they fall (to ~4%), it shows people are grabbing Treasuries to hide from the rain.
  • When they stabilize or rise, it often means the rain has stopped—and there’s more sunshine for stocks.

item.title: Build an Efficient, Lightweight, and Controlled Spec‑Driven Workflow with OpenSpec + Claude Code
item.content:encoded:
When teams start collaborating with AI coding assistants, clearly answering “what to build, how to build it, and how we know it’s done” becomes crucial. This guide walks you through a practical, reviewable, and traceable development workflow using OpenSpec (documentation‑driven development) together with Claude Code (an intelligent coding assistant).

Who this is for:

  • Teams that want specs before changes in multi‑person collaboration
  • People/teams that want AI assistants embedded into a standard workflow
  • Projects that require approval, archiving, or compliance control

Core Principles — Specs Are Truth

Section titled “Core Principles — Specs Are Truth”
  • Specs are truth: openspec/specs represents the currently delivered source of truth.
  • Propose before changes: any change impacting behavior/architecture/security/performance starts in changes/[id].
  • Three‑phase loop: Create change → Implement tasks → Archive and codify.
  • AI works to specs: Claude Code always uses OpenSpec as the authoritative context.

Install and Initialize

Section titled “Install and Initialize”

Install OpenSpec (global):

Initialize at the project root:

Initialization will:

  • Write a cross‑assistant AGENTS guide at the repo root
  • Generate the openspec/ directory structure
  • Establish unified collaboration instructions for Claude Code / Cursor / Codex, etc.
  • Later you can run openspec update to refresh the guidelines

Recommended directory structure (auto‑generated):

Collaborating with Claude Code

Section titled “Collaborating with Claude Code”

OpenSpec provides project context and process standards; Claude Code executes the Read → Generate → Implement → Verify cycle. After initialization, start your Claude Code session with prompts like these:

  • Fill in project context:

Please read openspec/project.md. Based on the repo’s current state, help me fully document project goals, tech stack, conventions, external dependencies, constraints, and naming standards.

  • Create the first change proposal:

I want to add “[your feature]”. Please create an OpenSpec change proposal (changes/[id]/) including proposal.md, tasks.md, and the relevant specs delta under changes/[id]/specs/.

  • Explain/enforce the workflow:

Using openspec/AGENTS.md, explain the three‑phase workflow and strictly follow it in subsequent steps: propose and validate first, implement after approval, archive when complete.

Tip: After installation, Codex/Windsurf/Cursor, etc. will also pick up the same guidelines so multiple assistants collaborate consistently.

Three‑Phase Workflow (from openspec/AGENTS.md)

Section titled “Three‑Phase Workflow (from openspec/AGENTS.md)”
  1. Create Change
  • When: new capability, breaking change, architecture/security/performance strategy changes
  • Steps:
    • Pick a unique change-id (kebab‑case, verb‑prefixed: add-, update-, remove-, refactor-)
    • Generate proposal.md, tasks.md, and design.md if needed
    • Write specs delta using operation headers: ## ADDED|MODIFIED|REMOVED|RENAMED Requirements
    • Validate: openspec validate <id> --strict
    • Only implement after approval
  1. Implement Change
  • Steps:
    • Read in order: proposal.md → design.md (optional) → tasks.md
    • Implement strictly in tasks.md order; check off each item when complete
    • Update overall task status only when all are completed
  1. Archive Change
  • After deployment:
    • Move changes/[id] to changes/archive/YYYY-MM-DD-[id]/
    • If capability behavior changed, update openspec/specs/
    • Run strict validation: openspec validate --strict
    • Optional: openspec archive [change] [--yes|-y] to auto‑archive (tooling changes may use --skip-specs)

Key Spec File Format (Important)

Section titled “Key Spec File Format (Important)”
  • Each requirement uses ### Requirement: ...
  • Each requirement must have at least one scenario using a level‑4 heading:

Do not use bullets or bold text instead of a scenario heading (the parser will fail).

  • Three types of delta changes:
    • ## ADDED Requirements for new capabilities
    • ## MODIFIED Requirements for behavior changes (paste the full updated requirement block, not a diff)
    • ## REMOVED Requirements for removals (include rationale and migration)
    • ## RENAMED Requirements for renames only

From Zero to One: A Happy Path

Section titled “From Zero to One: A Happy Path”
  1. Explore current state
  1. Choose a change ID and scaffold
  1. Write the delta (example)
  1. Strict validation
  1. Approval → Implementation
  • After approval, have Claude Code implement items in tasks.md step by step
  • Check off one item when it’s done; proceed until all are - [x]
  1. Archive and codify

Best Practices with Claude Code

Section titled “Best Practices with Claude Code”
  • Always let Claude Code “read” first: openspec/project.md, relevant specs/[capability]/spec.md, and changes/[id]/proposal.md|tasks.md
  • Execute strictly against tasks.md as the single source of truth; check off as you go
  • Prioritize edits directly related to the proposed change; avoid unrelated refactors
  • When ambiguous, ask 1–2 clarifying questions before scaffolding
  • When referencing code locations, use src/module.ts:42 single‑line pointers
  • Built‑in validation: openspec validate [change] --strict; if issues occur, use --json to diagnose

CLI Cheat Sheet

Section titled “CLI Cheat Sheet”

List / show / diff / validate

Section titled “List / show / diff / validate”

Common flags:

  • --json machine‑readable output
  • --type change|spec to specify the object type
  • --strict strict validation
  • --skip-specs archive only (skip specs update)
  • --yes|-y skip confirmation (good for CI)

Proposal vs. Direct Fix — When to Use Which?

Section titled “Proposal vs. Direct Fix — When to Use Which?”

Propose (recommended) when:

  • New features/capabilities
  • Breaking changes (API/Schema)
  • Architecture/pattern shifts
  • Performance/security strategy changes that affect behavior

Direct edits are fine when:

  • Bug fixes (restoring intended behavior)
  • Copy/format/comments
  • Non‑breaking dependency upgrades
  • Minor configuration tweaks
  • Tests that cover existing behavior

Common Pitfalls and Troubleshooting

Section titled “Common Pitfalls and Troubleshooting”
  • “Change must have at least one delta”
    • Check that changes/[id]/specs/ contains .md files
    • Ensure files include ## ADDED|MODIFIED|REMOVED operation headers
  • “Requirement must have at least one scenario”
    • Scenario headings must be #### Scenario: ... (level‑4 heading)
    • Do not use bullets or bold text
  • Delta parsing failures
    • Use openspec show [change] --json --deltas-only to debug
    • Compare with originals under openspec/specs/ and ensure MODIFIED is a full replacement block

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Use OpenSpec to make Requirements → Design → Tasks → Changes explicit from day one and treat them as the project’s source of truth. Then leverage Claude Code for efficient execution and collaboration so AI delivers within clear boundaries. The benefits:

  • Specs first to reduce rework; approvals up front to lower risk
  • Task closure with traceable outputs; archivable changes for reusable knowledge

item.title: Q3 2025 AI Chip Supply Chain Earnings Start Strong: ASML and TSMC Beat — Where Does NVIDIA Go from Here?
item.content:encoded:
Opening: Tech Earnings Season Kicks Off, Supply‑Chain Confidence Surges

Section titled “Opening: Tech Earnings Season Kicks Off, Supply‑Chain Confidence Surges”

As this earnings season shows, the AI chip supply chain is firing on all cylinders. ASML and TSMC both delivered upside surprises in their Q3 2025 results. More importantly, both turned distinctly more optimistic in their outlooks — a sharp contrast with their cautious tone three months ago.

ASML Q3 Highlights

Section titled “ASML Q3 Highlights”
  • Revenue €7.5B (≈$8.2B), gross margin 51.6%
  • Net income €2.125B, above market expectations
  • Q4 guidance raised sharply to €9.2–9.8B; gross margin 51%–53%
  • The key shift: management explicitly said 2026 revenue will not be below 2025, reversing prior uncertainty

TSMC’s Record Q3

Section titled “TSMC’s Record Q3”
  • Revenue NT$989.92B (≈$32.2B), up 39% y/y
  • Net income NT$452.3B (≈$14.8B), a record high
  • ADR EPS up 39% y/y; dynamic P/E only 33x, PEG < 1
  • Full‑year revenue growth target raised from 30% to 35%
  • Gross margin at a strong 59.5%, underscoring pricing power

The core message from both prints: AI acceleration is itself being accelerated.

Supply‑Chain Triangle: ASML → TSMC → NVIDIA

Section titled “Supply‑Chain Triangle: ASML → TSMC → NVIDIA”

To understand how these three companies interrelate, start with the key nodes in the AI chip value chain:

ASML — The Photolithography Monopolist

Section titled “ASML — The Photolithography Monopolist”
  • World’s only supplier of EUV lithography equipment
  • Each EUV system sells for >$200M; the latest High‑NA EUV is ~$380M per unit
  • All advanced‑node manufacturers (TSMC, Samsung, Intel) depend heavily on ASML

TSMC — The King of Advanced Foundry

Section titled “TSMC — The King of Advanced Foundry”
  • 61% global foundry share; 67% share in advanced nodes (<7nm)
  • Chips from all top AI designers (NVIDIA, Apple, AMD, etc.) are manufactured by TSMC
  • Mass‑production at 3nm; 2nm in progress

NVIDIA — The AI Chip Design Leader

Section titled “NVIDIA — The AI Chip Design Leader”
  • ~$4.38T market cap; data‑center business is ~88% of revenue
  • Relies entirely on TSMC’s advanced nodes to produce H100, H200, and the new Blackwell series
  • Blackwell generated ~$11B in FY25 Q4 revenue alone — the “fastest product ramp” in company history

The transmission goes: ASML’s EUV tools → TSMC’s advanced‑node capacity → NVIDIA’s AI chip supply. A bottleneck at any node constrains the entire chain.

Data: Stock‑Performance and Results Correlations

Section titled “Data: Stock‑Performance and Results Correlations”

Analyzing post‑earnings stock moves for these three from 2022–2025 reveals important patterns:

Finding 1: TSMC’s Link to NVIDIA Is Tighter

Section titled “Finding 1: TSMC’s Link to NVIDIA Is Tighter”

Our statistics show:

  • In the 10 trading days after TSMC earnings, NVIDIA’s return correlation is 0.70 (p=0.004) — statistically significant
  • After ASML earnings, NVIDIA’s 10‑day correlation is 0.49 (p=0.065) — weaker
  • Over 30‑day windows, TSMC↔NVIDIA correlation stays ~0.48; ASML drops to ~0.13

This supports the intuition that the nearer the link in the chain, the stronger the co‑movement. As NVIDIA’s direct supplier, TSMC’s capacity and process progress directly shape how many chips NVIDIA can ship.

Finding 2: Supplier Earnings Tend to Lift NVIDIA

Section titled “Finding 2: Supplier Earnings Tend to Lift NVIDIA”

On average:

  • In the 10 days after ASML reports, NVIDIA rose 3.8%; over 30 days, +14.2%
  • In the 10 days after TSMC reports, NVIDIA rose 2.1%; over 30 days, +15.8%
  • The effect was most pronounced in 2023 (the breakout year for AI): post‑ASML 30‑day average +19.8%; post‑TSMC +26.7%

Finding 3: Correlations Weakened in 2024–2025 but Remain Meaningful

Section titled “Finding 3: Correlations Weakened in 2024–2025 but Remain Meaningful”

As NVIDIA’s market cap surpassed $3T, its stock began to reflect more macro factors:

  • Fed policy expectations
  • U.S. export‑control policy toward China
  • Competition (AMD; hyperscaler in‑house chips)

Even so, supplier earnings remain pivotal indicators for NVIDIA — especially TSMC’s expansion plans and ASML’s EUV shipment cadence, which map to NVIDIA’s potential shipments over the next 12–18 months.

Share‑Price Performance Comparison

Section titled “Share‑Price Performance Comparison”

NVIDIA vs. ASML vs. TSMC since early 2022 (indexed to 100 at Jan 2022)

The chart shows NVIDIA up 497%, TSMC up 137%, and ASML up 27% over the period. The gap reflects differences in value capture:

  • NVIDIA: commands the highest value‑added layer via CUDA software ecosystem and leading chip design
  • TSMC: manufacturing profits are high (≈60% gross margin) but massive capex tempers stock elasticity
  • ASML: EUV monopoly, but the customer base is limited (principally TSMC, Samsung, Intel) and deliveries are long‑cycle, making growth steadier

Earnings‑Season by Year: Who Leads?

Section titled “Earnings‑Season by Year: Who Leads?”
YearNVIDIA ReturnASML ReturnTSMC Return
2022-51.5%-31.5%-42.2%
2023+245.8%+37.7%+40.5%
2024+178.8%-3.3%+94.5%
2025 (YTD)+33.9%+45.7%+54.3%

Key observations:

  • 2022 bear market: all three fell sharply; ASML fell least, showing defensiveness
  • 2023 “AI year one”: NVIDIA +246%; TSMC and ASML more moderate (+38–41%)
  • 2024 divergence: NVIDIA +179%; TSMC +95%; ASML −3% — reflecting China‑related limits and macro concerns
  • 2025 YTD: first time all three are rising together; TSMC/ASML outpacing NVIDIA as markets re‑rate upstream value

Three Key Signals from This Earnings Season

Section titled “Three Key Signals from This Earnings Season”

Signal 1: ASML’s 2026 Stance Flips 180 Degrees

Section titled “Signal 1: ASML’s 2026 Stance Flips 180 Degrees”

In July 2024 (Q2), ASML cautioned that “given rising macro and geopolitical uncertainty, we cannot confirm growth in 2026,” triggering a ~16% single‑day drop.

In Q3, management stated clearly that “2026 total revenue will not be below 2025,” stressing enduring AI‑driven demand. Drivers include:

  • Strong EUV orders: €5.4B net bookings in Q3, with €3.6B from EUV
  • High‑NA EUV shipments have begun, at higher price points (~$380M/unit)
  • TSMC, Samsung, Intel are all expanding; photolithography demand remains robust

Signal 2: TSMC Lifts 2025 Full‑Year Growth from 30% to 35%

Section titled “Signal 2: TSMC Lifts 2025 Full‑Year Growth from 30% to 35%”

In Q3, TSMC raised its 2025 USD revenue‑growth outlook from 30% to 35% — the second raise this year. CFO Wendell Huang noted: “We saw strong demand for advanced technologies in Q3, and as we enter Q4, we expect the strength to continue.”

More importantly, TSMC said 3nm and more advanced nodes are fully booked, with customers “competing for capacity,” indicating strong demand from NVIDIA, Apple, and others.

Signal 3: NVIDIA Blackwell Is Supply‑Constrained; Q4 Guide Above Street

Section titled “Signal 3: NVIDIA Blackwell Is Supply‑Constrained; Q4 Guide Above Street”

While NVIDIA has not yet reported Q3 (due Nov 19), Q2 already showed a rapid Blackwell ramp:

  • Q2 Blackwell revenue +17% q/q
  • Q3 guide $54.0B (±2%), above the Street’s $52.7B
  • CEO Jensen Huang: “Blackwell demand is surprising… we have achieved large‑scale mass production of Blackwell AI supercomputers.”

UBS lifted its Blackwell Q4 revenue estimate from $5B to $9B, signaling demand far above prior expectations.

Forecast: NVIDIA’s Q3 and the Road Ahead

Section titled “Forecast: NVIDIA’s Q3 and the Road Ahead”

Based on supplier prints and historical correlations, we estimate:

Q3 (reports Nov 19)

Section titled “Q3 (reports Nov 19)”
  • Revenue: consensus $54.0B; we see a modest beat to $54.5–55.0B
  • Data‑center revenue: $47–48B (≈88–89% mix)
  • Gross margin: 73–74%, a touch above Q2’s 72.7%
  • Q4 guide: $60–65B as Blackwell continues to ramp

Stock outlook

Section titled “Stock outlook”

Near term (1 month post‑print): if results land near expectations, shares could test the $200–210 range (≈11–17% above the current ~$180).

Through 2025 year‑end: Street average target ~$222 (+23%).

Upside case: if Blackwell capacity and demand both exceed expectations, HSBC’s $320 target is conceivable (+78%).

Key risks

Section titled “Key risks”
  • Macro slowdown: weaker global growth could curb enterprise IT spending
  • Rising competition: AMD’s MI300 and hyperscaler in‑house silicon (Google TPU, Amazon Trainium) chip away at share
  • Geopolitics: tighter U.S. export controls on China
  • Valuation pressure: current ~51x P/E sits well above the market average

Investment Takeaways: Positioning for the AI Chip Chain

Section titled “Investment Takeaways: Positioning for the AI Chip Chain”

Core holding: NVIDIA

Section titled “Core holding: NVIDIA”
  • Strengths: clear technology lead and a moat built on CUDA’s software ecosystem
  • Valuation: ~51x P/E not trivial, but ~1.3 PEG (on 35–40% growth) remains reasonable
  • Allocation: core position, ~50–60% of an AI‑theme sleeve

Quality anchor: TSMC

Section titled “Quality anchor: TSMC”
  • Strengths: leading advanced‑node manufacturing; diversified blue‑chip customers (Apple, NVIDIA, AMD, etc.); hard to replace
  • Valuation: ~33.6x P/E, below NVIDIA; PEG < 1 — attractive
  • Allocation: primary holding for balanced profiles, ~30–40%

Defensive ballast: ASML

Section titled “Defensive ballast: ASML”
  • Strengths: absolute EUV monopoly; high long‑term visibility
  • Weaknesses: slower growth; more sensitive to macro cycles; sold off in 2024 on China concerns
  • Allocation: defensive weight, ~10–20%

Note: Mind the transmission lags along the chain

Section titled “Note: Mind the transmission lags along the chain”

Our work suggests ASML/TSMC earnings impact NVIDIA with lag:

  • Short term (≤10 days): higher correlations, smaller absolute moves
  • Medium term (~30 days): weaker correlation, larger cumulative moves
  • Longer term (quarterly): all three converge toward fundamentals

Hence we do not recommend short‑term trading purely on supplier reports; focus on multi‑quarter trends.

Conclusion: The Acceleration of AI Acceleration Is Just Beginning

Section titled “Conclusion: The Acceleration of AI Acceleration Is Just Beginning”

ASML and TSMC’s Q3 beats are not only their own victories; they’re also barometers of supply‑chain health. As TSMC’s CFO put it, “We continue to see strong AI‑related demand, and we expect the trend to extend into 2026.”

Historically, NVIDIA has risen an average 15.8% in the 30 days post‑TSMC earnings, and 14.2% after ASML. With both suppliers beating this season, NVIDIA enters its Q3 report with a constructive setup.

For investors, the AI chip chain presents a rare case of full‑chain resonance: upstream ASML orderbooks are full; midstream TSMC is running flat out; downstream NVIDIA demand remains robust. In this backdrop, the acceleration of AI acceleration may be only getting started.

Risk Disclaimer: Investing involves risk. This article is for reference only and does not constitute investment advice.

item.title: How ChatGPT Helps Fix Bluetooth Device UI Chaos
item.content:encoded:
Scenario recap: You built a mobile app that scans nearby BLE devices. Your office/ward/desk is full of the same model, all with the same name. The scan results keep “jumping” as new devices arrive; just as users tap one, it gets pushed away — pure frustration for a PM.

This article doesn’t go into protocol internals. Instead, it shows how to use ChatGPT as your AI interaction partner: turn complex technical constraints into a UI your team can build, users can understand, and QA can validate.

1) Align on technical boundaries first, then pick the UI

Section titled “1) Align on technical boundaries first, then pick the UI”

For BLE scanning, a few facts directly shape your design:

  • Advertising payload: Useful info includes local name, service UUIDs, manufacturer data, Tx Power, etc. These can help you distinguish devices and filter. They’re read from the advertisement data structures.
  • iOS does not expose MAC addresses (privacy). Apps receive a CBPeripheral.identifier-style UUID, and it is not guaranteed to be permanently stable. Do not bake “display/remember MAC address” into any cross‑platform plan. Prefer short codes/manufacturer data from the advertisement as the differentiator.
  • Android can pre-filter and batch callbacks via ScanFilter and ScanSettings (e.g., filter by service UUID/manufacturer data and use setReportDelay for batched dispatch). This dramatically reduces UI jitter.

With these boundaries clear, ChatGPT can propose cross‑platform interaction patterns that are actionable, not just theory.

2) Break “I can’t tap the right one” into three solvable UX problems

Section titled “2) Break “I can’t tap the right one” into three solvable UX problems”

A. Recognition: Too many identical names — which one do I pick?

Section titled “A. Recognition: Too many identical names — which one do I pick?”

Solution: Generate a human‑recognizable short label per device.

  • Ask hardware to add a short code in the advertised name or Manufacturer Data (e.g., last 4 digits of S/N or batch + checksum). Surface it as a subtitle: Device Name · Short Code 3K7F. This is a common use of BLE advertisement.
  • iOS cannot show MAC: use the short code and/or service signature from the advertisement as the distinguishing factor. Don’t promise MAC in product specs.

B. Jitter: List jumps as it refreshes; finger misses the target

Section titled “B. Jitter: List jumps as it refreshes; finger misses the target”

Solution: Decouple “data changes” from “interface changes”.

  • Batched callbacks: On Android, enable ScanSettings.Builder#setReportDelay(xxx) so N updates arrive as a batch. Diff‑update the list once to reduce item shifts.
  • Freeze interactive zones: When the user long‑presses or enters multi‑select, freeze sorting and positions. Only update light fields inside items (e.g., RSSI value). Merge the full refresh after the action. This follows the principle “don’t let refreshes interrupt the user’s task”.

C. Decision load: Too noisy — help me narrow scope first

Section titled “C. Decision load: Too noisy — help me narrow scope first”

Solution: Put filter controls where the hand is.

  • Use Filter/Assist Chips above the list for one‑tap toggles like “Recently used only”, “Strong signal only”, “Connectable only”, “Target service only”. Chips are made for quick filtering.
  • Make filtering/sorting intent‑aligned — avoid large jumps that break focus. NN/g specifically recommends minimizing “view jumping” when applying filters.

3) A ready‑to‑ship UI package for PMs (via ChatGPT)

Section titled “3) A ready‑to‑ship UI package for PMs (via ChatGPT)”

You can paste the following to ChatGPT to polish copy, generate a prototype (describe it), or output component and acceptance lists.

(1) List item anatomy

Section titled “(1) List item anatomy”
  • Title: Device name (append batch/model if names collide)
  • Subtitle: Short code · Service overview (e.g., 3K7F · Battery, UpdateSvc)
  • Right‑side info: RSSI (supports the “tap the one you’re close to” mental model; if showing distance, prefer coarse buckets strong/medium/weak to avoid misleading precision)
  • Status badges: Recently used / New device (reduces decision cost). Use small badges or Chips (MD3).

(2) Top‑level quick filters (Chips)

Section titled “(2) Top‑level quick filters (Chips)”
  • Recently used only, Strong signal only (> −70 dBm), Connectable only, Target service only
  • Interaction policy: Keep the viewport stable on toggle. Try not to move the currently focused item.

(3) Sorting and grouping (avoid the alphabetical trap)

Section titled “(3) Sorting and grouping (avoid the alphabetical trap)”
  • Default: Sort by last interaction time descending (user mental model: the thing I just used should be first).
  • Alternative: Group into Recently used / New devices, then sort within groups by RSSI or last seen time. As NN/g notes, alphabetical sorting is rarely the best choice for decision tasks.

(4) Refresh and selection stability

Section titled “(4) Refresh and selection stability”
  • Combine Android batched callbacks with list diffing. When entering multi‑select/long‑press, freeze ordering; only “light‑update” fields inside items (e.g., RSSI).

(5) Cross‑platform identifier strategy

Section titled “(5) Cross‑platform identifier strategy”
  • Android: Use MAC (when available) or the advertised short code.
  • iOS: Use CBPeripheral.identifier plus advertised short code/service signature. Do not commit to displaying/remembering MAC.

4) Copy and naming you can drop in (EN/CN hints + field names)

Section titled “4) Copy and naming you can drop in (EN/CN hints + field names)”

Group headers (UI copy)

  • Recently Used Devices / 最近使用过的设备
  • New Devices / 新设备

Filter chips (UI copy)

  • Recently used / 只看最近使用
  • Strong signal only (> −70 dBm) / 只看强信号（> −70 dBm）
  • Connectable only / 只看可连接
  • Target service only / 只看目标服务

Interfaces/fields (snake_case)

5) Turn “plan → artifacts” with ChatGPT

Section titled “5) Turn “plan → artifacts” with ChatGPT”

Feed the “requirements + components” above to ChatGPT and ask for:

  • Prototype description for design: item hierarchy, chip interactions, empty‑state copy.
  • Engineering checklist: Android ScanFilter/ScanSettings config (with setReportDelay examples), iOS CoreBluetooth scanning and identifier usage cautions.
  • Acceptance cases: With 30+ devices, fluctuating RSSI, and stacked filters, can users still reliably select the intended device?

6) Takeaways: Know the boundaries, design the right interactions

Section titled “6) Takeaways: Know the boundaries, design the right interactions”
  • Lean on advertisement data to distinguish devices; don’t insist on MAC on iOS.
  • Use batched dispatch + frozen ordering to tame list jitter.
  • Make filtering/sorting intent‑centric with lightweight Chips; surface “Recently used/New” to lower selection cost.

With these constraints and patterns in hand, ChatGPT becomes your on‑call interaction consultant — bridging what’s buildable with what users grasp — turning the tiny pain of “I can’t tap it” into a chance for a big UX upgrade.

item.title: Claude Code 2.0.17 Update: Haiku 4.5 Takes Execution, Plan with Sonnet — Faster and Cheaper
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Today’s update is very kind to developers who code with Claude Code.

Claude Haiku 4.5 launches — cheaper and faster; Plan mode defaults to Sonnet for planning and switches to Haiku for execution. In practice, projects run smoother and your wallet hurts less. Official pricing/positioning and how this release hooks into Claude Code both support that conclusion.

Highlight 1: Lower cost, faster speed

Section titled “Highlight 1: Lower cost, faster speed”

Haiku 4.5: $1 / $5 (input/output per million tokens) — aimed at real‑time, low‑latency work, with optimizations for coding, sub‑agent collaboration, and computer‑use scenarios. Compared with Sonnet 4 from May, it’s well over 2× faster at about one‑third the cost, while delivering “near‑frontier” performance on many coding tasks.

Why “more economical”? Compare peers on pricing:

  • Sonnet 4.5: $3 / $15 (input/output).
  • Opus 4.1: $15 / $75 (input/output).

This means you can hand off execution steps that don’t need the “strongest brainpower” to Haiku 4.5. Bills slim down immediately and responses feel snappier. If you run many agents, hit backend services, or trigger calls frequently from your IDE, the value is obvious.

Highlight 2: Plan with Sonnet, execute with Haiku (the 2.0.17 default pairing)

One‑line takeaway: AI coding speed can’t fix fuzzy specs. To make Claude Code truly low‑friction, break every “etc.” into a checklist, turn acceptance into an executable script, and let automation run the tests.

Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Have you ever written a requirement like: “Show key device info on the home page (power, volume, etc.).”

Then at QA time, the AI only implements the first three. The “etc.” simply disappears. It’s not that the AI isn’t smart; the signal you gave wasn’t precise. Claude Code “does less” when your instructions are vague—it will reasonably but incompletely narrow the scope. That’s not a bug; it’s a boundary reminder for human‑AI collaboration.

By the way, Anthropic just bumped Haiku to 4.5: cheaper, faster, and coding performance close to Sonnet (now available in Copilot too). It’s faster, yes—but it still won’t auto‑complete your “etc.”

What you see: the less you write before “=”, the less you get after it

Section titled “What you see: the less you write before “=”, the less you get after it”
  • You wrote “power, volume, brightness, etc.”
  • Claude Code reads this as three explicit items + one implicit “etc.”
  • Result: code, automated tests, and docs all cover only the first three

It’s not AI “cutting corners.” It’s AI prioritizing what’s verifiable. Explicit items can produce code and tests; ambiguous ones get skipped. This shows up repeatedly in research and industry reports—with incomplete or vague specs, AI helpers are more likely to miss features, even when they produce code faster.

A copy‑and‑use solution: don’t let “etc.” ship to production

Section titled “A copy‑and‑use solution: don’t let “etc.” ship to production”

This workflow works for any app, admin, or web project. Steal it.

1) Turn every “etc.” into a data‑driven checklist

Section titled “1) Turn every “etc.” into a data‑driven checklist”

Write the nouns as a table and add “status, source, display rules, empty‑state policy, error policy” for each item. Example fields:

  • Name: Power / Volume / Brightness …
  • Domain: On/Off; 0–100 …
  • Source: local cache / backend API / Bluetooth …
  • Display: icon, label, unit
  • Empty: show “—” or greyed out
  • Error: timeout, disconnect, permission‑denied placeholders

The payoff: AI can generate complete UI + validation + empty states + error handling, not just “three components that look right.”

item.title: Ship a Rails feature in minutes with Claude Code: Document‑Driven dev + RSpec BDD
item.content:encoded:
Introduction

Section titled “Introduction”

Ever felt this pain? A device reports multiple states within a minute and your database turns into a wall of “noise”.

Here’s a general, reusable practice: in Rails, merge repeated reports that arrive within a short, configurable time window into a single “golden record”.

I’ll use Claude Code with a document‑driven approach: start from a single page of specs → generate BDD scenarios → validate with RSpec → minimal implementation → write findings back to the doc. The loop is fast, stable, and traceable. If you’re new to Claude Code, the official docs outline a clear playbook and best practices.

Our “public version” requirement (desensitized)

Section titled “Our “public version” requirement (desensitized)”

Business context (generic)

An “intelligent fitness band” may report multiple heart‑rate/status events within one minute. To avoid redundancy, we want to:

  • Within a configurable time window (default 1 minute), grouped by device and type, merge multiple events into one;
  • Keep the latest record within the window (i.e., the last one wins);
  • Write to a unified work record table, ensure idempotency, and keep merge provenance for audit and traceability.

Document‑Driven

Put the above into a single “feature spec” document. That document doubles as the product contract and acceptance criteria. From it, we derive BDD scenarios and tests. This follows the same spirit as “Specification by Example/ATDD/BDD”: examples are the single source of truth.

Claude Code + BDD: from doc to executable acceptance

Section titled “Claude Code + BDD: from doc to executable acceptance”

Why Claude Code

It’s a terminal‑native coding copilot that actively pulls context. It connects code, docs, dependencies, and scaffolding, turning ideas into runnable structure quickly. The docs include hands‑on tips such as how to organize repositories so the agent “understands” your intent.

Prompt template (paste into Claude Code)

Role: Senior Rails engineer + test coach Goal: Implement “device report merge” as a reusable capability Deliverables:

  1. Based on the spec below, generate RSpec BDD scenarios and edge cases (Rails + Capybara/request/service layer);
  2. Provide a minimal implementation skeleton (service object, queries, transaction, idempotency strategy);
  3. Propose rollback and audit logging;
  4. Write all assumptions back to the doc under “Open Questions”. Attachment: the feature spec (paste the “public version” requirement above)

Why RSpec + BDD

RSpec reads like behavior. Tests are documentation. Rails’ official guide also clarifies test layers. With Capybara/request specs you can do API acceptance and system flows.

Acceptance examples (trimmed BDD thinking)

Section titled “Acceptance examples (trimmed BDD thinking)”

User story

  • As a data platform, within one minute, multiple reports of the same device and record type should be merged into one, taking the last record as the truth. This keeps queries clean and metrics correct.

Key scenarios

  • In‑window merge: t=00:10 and 00:40 → save 1 row, payload from 00:40.
  • Cross‑window no‑merge: t=00:10 and 01:15 → save 2 rows.
  • Idempotent writes: repeated requests do not produce duplicate merge results.
  • Auditable: keep source IDs and window parameters.

Tip: Put these examples in the doc/feature file so they serve both discussion and automated tests.

RSpec skeleton (snippet)

Section titled “RSpec skeleton (snippet)”

Reference: See RSpec/Capybara conventions for feature tests and dependency constraints.

Rails minimal implementation (map)

Section titled “Rails minimal implementation (map)”
  • Entry point: service object RecordMerger.call(device_id:, record_type:, window:)
  • Query: same device + same type + recorded_at within the “natural time window”
  • Merge strategy:
    • Use the record with the max recorded_at as the base data
    • Persist the rest as the provenance set, e.g., merged_from: [ids...]
  • Idempotency & concurrency:
    • App‑level mutual exclusion by device + window (e.g., with_advisory_lock)
    • Unique index on the critical key (device + window start, or a computed idempotency key)
  • Audit:
    • Record merge_window_sec, merged_count, merged_from
    • Emit event logs for tracing and replay

For broader coverage, add request/system tests to verify API I/O. Rails’ testing guide explains test responsibilities across layers.

Make AI truly accelerate: engineering checklist

Section titled “Make AI truly accelerate: engineering checklist”
  • Keep the spec in the repo root with a consistent name so Claude Code can auto‑pull context.
  • Advance one micro‑goal at a time: get “in‑window merge” green first, then expand to idempotency and audit.
  • Write back to the doc frequently: new edge cases, pitfalls, and decisions go to “Open Questions/Decision Log”.
  • Backups and milestones: long sessions may compress context—split sessions at milestones, tag them, and keep local snapshots. AI is a power tool; you are still the craftsperson.

Industry feedback echoes this: Claude Code is rolling out across teams, long‑context models keep improving, and large‑repo analysis is getting steadier.

What the deliverables look like (team template)

Section titled “What the deliverables look like (team template)”
  1. One‑page feature spec (background, goal, scope, glossary, examples, open questions)
  2. RSpec suite (service + request/system tests, with edges and regression)
  3. Service object + indexes/locks (minimal viable)
  4. Event log + dashboards (merge hit rate, storage saved, query latency deltas)

Value is measurable: docs are the contract; tests are the acceptance; logs are the operational review.

Iteration stays smooth: adding a “2‑minute window” or “window per type” is just add examples → run tests → small tweaks.

Conclusion

Section titled “Conclusion”

Document‑Driven + BDD does not mean “write more docs”; it means making the doc an executable product contract. With Claude Code, you compress the chain from idea → tests → implementation → review to hours. Collaboration gets smoother, delivery more stable, and reading the code feels like reading a story.

How would you land this merge capability in your team? Any stronger idempotency key designs? Share in the comments.
